articles.headline: In Halting Ant’s I.P.O., China Sends a Warning to Business
articles.snippet: Investors in what would have been the world’s largest share sale are getting refunds, as Beijing shows entrepreneurs the importance of listening to the Communist Party.
articles.abstract: Investors in what would have been the world’s largest share sale are getting refunds, as Beijing shows entrepreneurs the importance of listening to the Communist Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: This was supposed to be the week that one of China’s biggest tech companies threw the most lucrative coming-out party in history, sending a swaggering message about the country’s economic might during the pandemic.
articles.byline: By Raymond Zhong

articles.headline: A Motorcycle Rally in a Pandemic? ‘We Kind of Knew What Was Going to Happen’
articles.snippet: Infectious-disease experts warned about the risk of cramming revelers into the Black Hills of South Dakota. But it was the annual Sturgis rally, and bikers were coming no matter what.
articles.abstract: Infectious-disease experts warned about the risk of cramming revelers into the Black Hills of South Dakota. But it was the annual Sturgis rally, and bikers were coming no matter what.
articles.lead_paragraph: STURGIS, S.D. — Albert Aguirre was amped as he and a buddy skimmed across the South Dakota plains, heading to join 460,000 bikers for a motorcycle rally shaping up to be a Woodstock of unmasked, uninhibited coronavirus defiance.
articles.byline: By Mark Walker and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Jobs Report Shows Gains but Vulnerability to New Virus Surge
articles.snippet: U.S. payrolls grew by 638,000 in October and unemployment fell to 6.9%, but lockdowns could stifle a rebound in restaurant and retail work.
articles.abstract: U.S. payrolls grew by 638,000 in October and unemployment fell to 6.9%, but lockdowns could stifle a rebound in restaurant and retail work.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy continues to heal from the devastating effects of the first wave of the coronavirus pandemic last spring, but a new wave of cases threatens prospects for sustained growth.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: New York Post Shifts Tone on Trump as a Top Editor Plans His Own Exit
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch’s tabloid has turned critical as the president seems headed to defeat. Col Allan, a wizard there, says he plans to retire next year.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch’s tabloid has turned critical as the president seems headed to defeat. Col Allan, a wizard there, says he plans to retire next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month The New York Post called President Trump “an invincible hero, who not only survived every dirty trick the Democrats threw at him, but the Chinese virus as well.” Then it published front-page articles trying to link the contents of a laptop said to belong to Hunter Biden to his father, Joseph R. Biden Jr.
articles.byline: By Katie Robertson

articles.headline: With No Evidence of Fraud, Trump Fails to Make Headway on Legal Cases
articles.snippet: The president appeared to have little path through the courts to shift the outcome of the election, leaving him reliant on long shots like recounts or pressure on state legislatures.
articles.abstract: The president appeared to have little path through the courts to shift the outcome of the election, leaving him reliant on long shots like recounts or pressure on state legislatures.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s bellicose pledge to fight the outcome of the election in the courts crashed on Friday into skeptical judges, daunting Electoral College math and a lack of evidence for his claims of fraud.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg, Nick Corasaniti and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: Praying, Dancing, Waiting: Americans Hang On for the Election’s End
articles.snippet: Some in Philadelphia danced as Joseph R. Biden Jr. pulled ahead in their state. Trump supporters held out hope.
articles.abstract: Some in Philadelphia danced as Joseph R. Biden Jr. pulled ahead in their state. Trump supporters held out hope.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson, Audra D. S. Burch and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: Leading in Pennsylvania, Biden Tells Nation, ‘We’re Going to Win This Race’
articles.snippet: Joe Biden also pulled ahead in Georgia, and maintained leads in Nevada and Arizona. President Trump and his team weighed legal options, but lawsuits this week have had no meaningful effect on the tabulation of ballots.
articles.abstract: Joe Biden also pulled ahead in Georgia, and maintained leads in Nevada and Arizona. President Trump and his team weighed legal options, but lawsuits this week have had no meaningful effect on the tabulation of ballots.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Senate Majority in Balance as Perdue Re-election Race Goes to Runoff in Georgia
articles.snippet: Mr. Perdue, a first-term Republican, narrowly failed to clear 50 percent of the vote, sending the race to a January runoff that, along with another runoff contest, will probably determine which party controls the Senate.
articles.abstract: Mr. Perdue, a first-term Republican, narrowly failed to clear 50 percent of the vote, sending the race to a January runoff that, along with another runoff contest, will probably determine which party controls the Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Control of the Senate hung in the balance on Friday in Georgia after Senator David Perdue, a Republican, fell just short of the majority of votes he needed to win re-election, setting the stage for a second January runoff in the rapidly changing state.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: For Millions Deep in Student Loan Debt, Bankruptcy Is No Easy Fix
articles.snippet: It’s an extremely difficult debt to discharge, and only a few hundred people a year even try. Here are the stories of some who succeeded — mostly.
articles.abstract: It’s an extremely difficult debt to discharge, and only a few hundred people a year even try. Here are the stories of some who succeeded — mostly.
articles.lead_paragraph: With two mortgages, three children and $83,000 in student loan debt, the financial strain finally became too much for George A. Johnson and Melanie Raney-Johnson.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Biden Wins Presidency, Ending Four Tumultuous Years Under Trump
articles.snippet: Joseph R. Biden Jr. achieved victory offering a message of healing and unity. He will return to Washington facing a daunting set of crises.
articles.abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. achieved victory offering a message of healing and unity. He will return to Washington facing a daunting set of crises.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joseph Robinette Biden Jr. was elected the 46th president of the United States on Saturday, promising to restore political normalcy and a spirit of national unity to confront raging health and economic crises, and making Donald J. Trump a one-term president after four years of tumult in the White House.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: A President-Elect Shaped by Tragedy and Tradition
articles.snippet: Joseph R. Biden Jr. has spent his career devoted to institutions and relationships. And those are the tools he will rely on to govern a fractured nation.
articles.abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. has spent his career devoted to institutions and relationships. And those are the tools he will rely on to govern a fractured nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thirty-three years ago, he was the fast-talking junior senator from Delaware with a chip on his shoulder, desperate to prove his gravitas during a brief, ill-fated presidential run.
articles.byline: By Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Kamala Harris Makes History as First Woman and Woman of Color as Vice President
articles.snippet: Ms. Harris, the daughter of an Indian mother and Jamaican father, has risen higher in the country’s leadership than any woman ever before her.
articles.abstract: Ms. Harris, the daughter of an Indian mother and Jamaican father, has risen higher in the country’s leadership than any woman ever before her.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the earliest days of her childhood, Kamala Harris was taught that the road to racial justice was long.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Biden Knows Washington Has Changed. He’s Less Sure He Has To.
articles.snippet: Preparing to assume the presidency in a divided country, Joe Biden confronts the ultimate test of his principal theory of governance: that compromise is good and modest progress is still progress.
articles.abstract: Preparing to assume the presidency in a divided country, Joe Biden confronts the ultimate test of his principal theory of governance: that compromise is good and modest progress is still progress.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: How Joe Biden Won the Presidency
articles.snippet: Joseph R. Biden Jr. campaigned as a sober and conventional presence, concerned about the “soul of the country.” He correctly judged the character of the country, and benefited from President Trump’s missteps.
articles.abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. campaigned as a sober and conventional presence, concerned about the “soul of the country.” He correctly judged the character of the country, and benefited from President Trump’s missteps.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a January evening in 2019, Joseph R. Biden Jr. placed a call to the mayor of Los Angeles, Eric Garcetti, a personal friend and political ally who had just announced he would not pursue the Democratic nomination for president.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns, Jonathan Martin and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: The Digital Nomads Did Not Prepare for This
articles.snippet: They moved to exotic locales to work through the pandemic in style. But now tax trouble, breakups and Covid guilt are setting in.
articles.abstract: They moved to exotic locales to work through the pandemic in style. But now tax trouble, breakups and Covid guilt are setting in.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a certain kind of worker, the pandemic presented a rupture in the space-time-career continuum. Many Americans were stuck, tied down by children or lost income or obligations to take care of the sick. But for those who were unencumbered, with steady jobs that were doable from anywhere, it was a moment to grab destiny and bend employment to their favor.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith

articles.headline: How Georgia Turned From Reliably Republican to Political Ground Zero
articles.snippet: Joe Biden’s narrow lead in Georgia and the runoffs that will determine control of the Senate have raised questions as to whether 2020 is a Trumpian aberration or a long-anticipated political shift.
articles.abstract: Joe Biden’s narrow lead in Georgia and the runoffs that will determine control of the Senate have raised questions as to whether 2020 is a Trumpian aberration or a long-anticipated political shift.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARIETTA, Ga. — It took a lifetime for Angie Jones to become a Democrat.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: As Biden Plans Transition, Republicans Decline to Recognize His Election
articles.snippet: Former President George W. Bush and a handful of other Republicans congratulated the president-elect, but most party leaders stayed quiet or urged President Trump to fight.
articles.abstract: Former President George W. Bush and a handful of other Republicans congratulated the president-elect, but most party leaders stayed quiet or urged President Trump to fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. prepared on Sunday to start building his administration, even as Republican leaders and scores of party lawmakers refrained from acknowledging his victory out of apparent deference to President Trump, who continued to refuse to concede.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater

articles.headline: In a Divided Washington, Biden Could Still Exert Economic Power
articles.snippet: If Republicans control the Senate, a Biden administration could take a cue from President Trump and find ways to act unilaterally on some economic issues.
articles.abstract: If Republicans control the Senate, a Biden administration could take a cue from President Trump and find ways to act unilaterally on some economic issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will take office in January with a weak economy weighed down by the resurgence of the coronavirus, millions of Americans still unemployed and businesses struggling and shuttering as winter bears down.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport, Jeanna Smialek, Ana Swanson and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: A ‘Terrifying’ Coronavirus Surge Will Land in Biden’s Lap
articles.snippet: Total coronavirus cases in the U.S. surpassed 10 million on Sunday. Experts say the virus is spreading out of control and could grow worse before President-elect Biden takes office.
articles.abstract: Total coronavirus cases in the U.S. surpassed 10 million on Sunday. Experts say the virus is spreading out of control and could grow worse before President-elect Biden takes office.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Hours after President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. declared the coronavirus a top priority, the magnitude of his task became starkly clear on Sunday as the nation surpassed 10 million cases and sank deeper into the grip of what could become the worst chapter of the pandemic yet.
articles.byline: By Sarah Mervosh, Mitch Smith and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio

articles.headline: The Trump Presidency Is Ending. So Is Maggie Haberman’s Wild Ride.
articles.snippet: For the last four years, the Times reporter has been the human incarnation of a nation riveted, like it or not, by Donald Trump.
articles.abstract: For the last four years, the Times reporter has been the human incarnation of a nation riveted, like it or not, by Donald Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maggie Haberman lives rent-free in Donald Trump’s head, all over the front page of The New York Times and also in a brick house in an unglamorous Brooklyn neighborhood out beyond the Citi Bikes and stately brownstones. On election night, as the votes started coming in, she was seated at her dining room table with her husband and one of her three children, drinking from a liter bottle of Foodtown raspberry seltzer, eating leftover Kit Kats from Halloween, typing and texting, and, still, still, working her sources.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: How Democrats Missed Trump’s Appeal to Latino Voters
articles.snippet: The election was a referendum on Trump’s America, but plenty of Latino voters liked it just fine.
articles.abstract: The election was a referendum on Trump’s America, but plenty of Latino voters liked it just fine.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Democrats thought it would be enough.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina

articles.headline: The End of ‘America First’: How Biden Says He Will Re-engage With the World
articles.snippet: Those who have known President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. for decades say they expect him to move carefully, providing reassurance with a few big symbolic acts.
articles.abstract: Those who have known President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. for decades say they expect him to move carefully, providing reassurance with a few big symbolic acts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. makes no secret of the speed with which he plans to bury “America First” as a guiding principle of the nation’s foreign policy.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Business Leaders, Drawn Into Fray by Trump, See Chance to Step Back
articles.snippet: Since President Trump took office, corporate America has been thrust into the culture wars like never before. The atmosphere would probably be different with a Biden administration.
articles.abstract: Since President Trump took office, corporate America has been thrust into the culture wars like never before. The atmosphere would probably be different with a Biden administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the moment President Trump took office, big businesses were thrust into the culture wars like never before.
articles.byline: By David Gelles

articles.headline: Thanksgiving Will Soon Empty Campuses. Will Students Bring Coronavirus Home?
articles.snippet: Experts worry that some of the hundreds of thousands of departing students will be “little ticking time bombs.”
articles.abstract: Experts worry that some of the hundreds of thousands of departing students will be “little ticking time bombs.”
articles.lead_paragraph: As Thanksgiving approaches, millions of Americans are weighing the risk of pandemic travel against the yearning to visit friends and family. But one group seems all but certain to be heading home in large numbers just in time for turkey and holiday gatherings: college students.
articles.byline: By Shawn Hubler
